qas.question: Which other Austrian scholar and friend of Popper also worked near him at the London School of Economics?
In which year did Popper write Hayek a letter expressing his intellectual debt to him?
Who did Popper say was the only thinker who might have had a greater influence on him than Hayek?
Which of Hayek's publications was dedicated to Popper?

answers.text: Studies in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics

qas.question: Who has a long rivalry with Popper?
Who did Hayek write a letter to in 1944?
Who did Alfred Tarski say he had learned more from than any other living thinker?
When did Studies in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics come out?

context: While there is some dispute as to the matter of influence, <b6_0>Popper<b6_0/> had a long-standing and close friendship with economist <a0_0><b5_0>Friedrich Hayek<b5_0/><a0_0/>, who was also brought to the London School of <a1_0>Economics<a1_0/> from Vienna. Each found support and similarities in the other's work, citing each other often, though not without qualification. In a letter to <b8_0>Hayek<b8_0/> in <a2_0>1944<a2_0/>, <b7_0>Popper<b7_0/> stated, "I think I have learnt more from you than from any other living thinker, except perhaps <a3_0>Alfred Tarski<a3_0/>." Popper dedicated his Conjectures and Refutations to Hayek. For his part, Hayek dedicated a collection of papers, <a4_0>Studies in Philosophy, Politics, and Economics<a4_0/>, to Popper, and in 1982 said, "...ever since his Logik der Forschung first came out in <b9_0>1934<b9_0/>, I have been a complete adherent to his general theory of methodology."
